project.project_name: Fused Air Quality Surface Using Downscaling (FAQSD)

resource.resource_name: US Environmental Protection Agency Fused Air Quality Surface Using Downscaling (EPA FAQSD)
resource.resource_description: The U.S. Environmental Protection Agency, Fused Air Quality Surface Using Downscaling (EPA FAQSD) presents modeled PM2.5 (daily average) and O3 (daily 8-hr maximum) surfaces. Predictions are generated from a Bayesian space-time downscaling fusion model that uses both air quality monitoring data from the National Air Monitoring Stations/State and Local Air Monitoring Stations and numerical output data from the EPA Community Multiscale Air Quality (CMAQ) database. Data are available at the 2010 census tract level for 2002-2016.

publication.citation: Berrocal, V., Gelfand, A. E. and Holland, D. M. (2012). Space-time fusion under error in computer model output: an application to modeling air quality. Biometrics 68, 837-848
Berrocal, V., Gelfand, A. E. and Holland, D. M. (2010). A bivariate space-time downscaler under space and time misalignment. The Annals of Applied Statistics 4, 1942-1975
Berrocal, V., Gelfand, A. E., and Holland, D. M. (2010). A spatio- temporal downscaler for output from numerical models. J. of Agricultural, Biological, and Environmental Statistics 15, 176-197

key_variables: Daily fine particulate matter (PM2.5) and daily 8-hour maximum ozone (O3) air pollution concentration predictions and associated prediction standard error
example_metrics: Daily air pollutant concentrations for Census tract containing geocoded address

intended_use.value: Geospatial exposure assessment for public health studies on shorter-term or longer-term outcomes
Geospatial exposure assessment at the individual-level or population-level

strengths: Dataset supports analysis of shorter-term (e.g., daily, weekly, monthly) exposure to air pollution across the contiguous US using consistent methods
Dataset includes information about uncertainty in model predictions (i.e., standard error values)
Data available for geographic units commonly used in population-level analyses (i.e., Census tract) in tabular format
limitations: Dataset cannot be used to compare exposures within the same Census tract or at different times of day
Dataset cannot be used to compare exposures within the same Census tract or at different times of day
